question: Question_07_(b)
sols:
We will prove this by induction on $n$.

First, for $n=1$, since $b_1=2$ we clearly have that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1 \leq b_1 \leq 2\end{align*}

Now, let us assume that the statement is true up to $n=m$, that is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1 \leq b_n \leq 2 \quad\text{ for } n=1, \dots, m\end{align*} and let us show that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1 \leq b_{m+1} \leq 2\end{align*}

By definition of the sequence ${ b_n }$ we have that

\begin{align*}b_{m+1} = \frac{b_m+\sqrt{b_m}}{2}\end{align*}

Since $b_m$ $\leq$ 2 we have that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\sqrt{b_m} \leq \sqrt{2} \leq 2\end{align*}

and so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
b_{m+1} = \frac{b_m + \sqrt{b_m}}{2} \leq \frac{2+2}{2} = 2\end{align*}

And since $b_m$ $\geq$ 1 we have that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\sqrt{b_m} \geq 1\end{align*}

and so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
b_{m+1} = \frac{b_m + \sqrt{b_m}}{2} \geq \frac{1+1}{2} = 1\end{align*}

These two arguments show that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1 \leq b_{m+1} \leq 2\end{align*}

and hence conclude our proof.
